nodes.name: Alpha-synuclein
nodes.function: Presynaptic protein involved in neurotransmitter release
nodes.role_in_PD: Aggregates in Lewy bodies, contributing to neurodegeneration

nodes.name: Phosphorylated Alpha-synuclein
nodes.function: Pathologically modified form of alpha-synuclein
nodes.role_in_PD: Key component in Lewy body formation, indicating disease progression

nodes.name: Tau Protein
nodes.function: Microtubule-associated protein stabilizing neuronal cytoskeleton
nodes.role_in_PD: Elevated levels or abnormal phosphorylation may be associated with cognitive aspects of PD

nodes.name: Phosphorylated Tau (p-tau)
nodes.function: Abnormally phosphorylated form of Tau protein
nodes.role_in_PD: May contribute to neurodegeneration, particularly in cognitive decline associated with PD

nodes.name: Beta-synuclein
nodes.function: Synuclein isoform thought to inhibit alpha-synuclein aggregation
nodes.role_in_PD: May have a protective or counterbalancing function against alpha-synuclein toxicity

nodes.name: Neurofilament Light Chain (NfL)
nodes.function: Structural component of neuronal cytoskeleton, released upon damage
nodes.role_in_PD: Elevated levels reflect ongoing neuronal injury

nodes.name: DJ-1
nodes.function: Redox-sensitive protein with antioxidant properties and regulates mitochondrial quality control
nodes.role_in_PD: Loss of function increases oxidative stress, accelerating neuronal damage

nodes.name: Parkin
nodes.function: E3 ubiquitin ligase involved in proteostasis and mitophagy
nodes.role_in_PD: Mutations reduce mitochondrial quality control, promoting cell death

nodes.name: PINK1
nodes.function: Mitochondrial kinase that helps protect mitochondria from damage
nodes.role_in_PD: Loss of PINK1 impairs mitochondrial clearance, leading to dysfunction

nodes.name: LRRK2
nodes.function: Kinase protein implicated in cytoskeletal dynamics and vesicular trafficking
nodes.role_in_PD: Mutations increase kinase activity, potentially disrupting neuronal homeostasis

nodes.name: GCase (Glucocerebrosidase)
nodes.function: Lysosomal enzyme breaking down glucocerebrosides
nodes.role_in_PD: Reduced activity linked to alpha-synuclein accumulation

nodes.name: Cathepsin D
nodes.function: Lysosomal protease crucial for degrading misfolded proteins
nodes.role_in_PD: Helps clear alpha-synuclein aggregates; impaired activity may contribute to protein accumulation

nodes.name: UCH-L1
nodes.function: Ubiquitin C-terminal hydrolase involved in protein degradation
nodes.role_in_PD: Implicated in maintaining proteostasis; mutations or reduced activity may accelerate neuronal damage

nodes.name: SIRT2
nodes.function: Sirtuin family deacetylase influencing metabolism, stress resistance, and protein homeostasis
nodes.role_in_PD: May modulate alpha-synuclein toxicity and neuronal resilience through deacetylation pathways

nodes.name: Nurr1
nodes.function: Nuclear receptor and transcription factor required for dopaminergic neuron development and maintenance
nodes.role_in_PD: Downregulation leads to impaired dopamine synthesis and neuronal survival, potentially exacerbating PD pathology

nodes.name: Serotonin
nodes.function: Regulates mood, appetite, sleep, and various non-motor functions
nodes.role_in_PD: Altered serotonin levels can contribute to mood disturbances and may influence cognitive aspects in PD

nodes.name: Dopamine
nodes.function: Essential neurotransmitter for motor control in the nigrostriatal pathway
nodes.role_in_PD: Deficiency occurs with loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra

nodes.name: Norepinephrine
nodes.function: Modulates alertness, stress response, and autonomic functions
nodes.role_in_PD: Loss of noradrenergic neurons in the locus coeruleus may affect both motor and non-motor symptoms, including tremor

nodes.name: Acetylcholine
nodes.function: Plays a key role in motor control, cognitive function, and parasympathetic autonomic activity
nodes.role_in_PD: Cholinergic system imbalances can exacerbate motor symptoms and cognitive decline in later stages of PD

nodes.name: Glutamate
nodes.function: Primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS
nodes.role_in_PD: Excessive glutamatergic activity can promote excitotoxicity, potentially exacerbating mitochondrial and neuronal damage

nodes.name: Substantia Nigra pars compacta (SNc)
nodes.function: Primary source of dopaminergic neurons projecting to the striatum for motor control
nodes.role_in_PD: Degeneration of SNc neurons leads to reduced dopamine and hallmark motor symptoms (bradykinesia, tremor)

nodes.name: Striatum (Caudate/Putamen)
nodes.function: Integrates dopaminergic input from the SNc for motor planning and reward-related processes
nodes.role_in_PD: Dopamine depletion in the striatum contributes to impaired motor function

nodes.name: Locus Coeruleus
nodes.function: Primary noradrenergic nucleus involved in arousal and stress response
nodes.role_in_PD: Degeneration contributes to noradrenergic deficits, affecting tremor and autonomic dysfunction

nodes.name: Raphe Nuclei
nodes.function: Main source of serotonin in the brain, regulating mood and other non-motor functions
nodes.role_in_PD: Serotonergic dysfunction can exacerbate mood disturbances and certain non-motor symptoms

nodes.name: Nucleus Basalis of Meynert
nodes.function: Primary cholinergic nucleus projecting to the cortex, involved in attention and cognition
nodes.role_in_PD: Degeneration leads to cholinergic deficits, contributing to cognitive decline

nodes.name: Ventral Tegmental Area (VTA)
nodes.function: Major dopaminergic center projecting to limbic and cortical areas, influencing motivation, reward, and cognitive functions
nodes.role_in_PD: Dopaminergic neurons here can be affected, contributing to reward-system deficits and non-motor symptoms (e.g., mood, motivation)

nodes.name: Hippocampus
nodes.function: Critical for memory formation and spatial navigation
nodes.role_in_PD: May exhibit alpha-synuclein pathology and atrophy; contributes to cognitive decline and depression/anxiety symptoms in PD

nodes.name: Amygdala
nodes.function: Key role in emotional processing, fear, and reward-based behaviors
nodes.role_in_PD: Involvement may lead to emotional dysregulation, heightened anxiety, and changes in reward processing

nodes.name: Motor Cortex
nodes.function: Primary region responsible for voluntary motor commands
nodes.role_in_PD: Receives abnormal basal ganglia output due to reduced dopamine; contributes to bradykinesia and other motor impairments

nodes.name: Prefrontal Cortex
nodes.function: Involved in executive functions, decision-making, and working memory
nodes.role_in_PD: Dopaminergic depletion and potential alpha-synuclein spread can result in executive dysfunction and cognitive decline

nodes.name: Subthalamic Nucleus (STN)
nodes.function: Part of the basal ganglia circuit, modulating output to the thalamus and cortex
nodes.role_in_PD: Often exhibits hyperactivity when dopaminergic input is lost; deep brain stimulation here can reduce motor symptoms

nodes.name: Pedunculopontine Nucleus (PPN)
nodes.function: Associated with gait, posture, and arousal; contains cholinergic and glutamatergic neurons
nodes.role_in_PD: Degeneration or dysfunction may contribute to gait disturbances and balance issues

nodes.name: Olfactory Bulb
nodes.function: Processes olfactory (smell) information
nodes.role_in_PD: Earliest site of alpha-synuclein pathology in many PD cases; associated with loss of smell (hyposmia)

nodes.name: Nucleus Accumbens (NAc)
nodes.function: Central hub in the mesolimbic (reward) pathway, receiving dopaminergic input from the VTA
nodes.role_in_PD: Dysregulation in the NAc can contribute to impulse control disorders and DDS in PD

nodes.name: SNCA
nodes.function: Encodes alpha-synuclein, a presynaptic protein involved in neurotransmitter release
nodes.role_in_PD: Point mutations, multiplications, or triplications of SNCA lead to familial PD with Lewy bodies

nodes.name: LRRK2 (Gene)
nodes.function: Encodes leucine-rich repeat kinase 2, involved in cytoskeletal dynamics and vesicular trafficking
nodes.role_in_PD: Mutations are the most common cause of autosomal-dominant PD

nodes.name: PRKN
nodes.function: Encodes Parkin (an E3 ubiquitin ligase) that aids in mitophagy
nodes.role_in_PD: Mutations cause early-onset PD (PARK2), disrupting mitochondrial quality control

nodes.name: PINK1 (Gene)
nodes.function: Encodes PTEN-induced putative kinase 1 (PINK1), crucial for mitochondrial protection
nodes.role_in_PD: Loss-of-function mutations cause autosomal recessive early-onset PD (PARK6)

nodes.name: PARK7 (DJ-1 Gene)
nodes.function: Encodes DJ-1, a redox-sensitive protein with antioxidant properties
nodes.role_in_PD: Mutations cause autosomal recessive PD (PARK7); impair cellular defense against oxidative stress

nodes.name: GBA
nodes.function: Encodes glucocerebrosidase (GCase), a lysosomal enzyme that breaks down glucocerebrosides
nodes.role_in_PD: Heterozygous mutations are a significant genetic risk factor for PD, increasing alpha-synuclein aggregation

nodes.name: Bradykinesia
nodes.description: Slowness of movement
nodes.role_in_PD: One of the cardinal motor symptoms of PD, resulting from decreased dopaminergic input to the motor pathways

nodes.name: Tremor
nodes.description: Involuntary rhythmic shaking
nodes.role_in_PD: Often a resting tremor, linked to altered dopaminergic and noradrenergic signaling

nodes.name: Rigidity
nodes.description: Increased resistance to passive movement
nodes.role_in_PD: Caused by imbalance in basal ganglia output due to loss of dopamine

nodes.name: Postural Instability
nodes.description: Impaired balance and coordination
nodes.role_in_PD: Associated with loss of postural reflexes and changes in brainstem control of gait

nodes.name: Freezing of Gait
nodes.description: Sudden inability to initiate or continue stepping
nodes.role_in_PD: Linked to dysfunction in motor circuitry, including the basal ganglia and pedunculopontine nucleus

nodes.name: Cognitive Decline
nodes.description: Impairment in memory, attention, and executive functions
nodes.role_in_PD: Can progress to dementia; related to cortical and subcortical pathology (including alpha-synuclein, tau)

nodes.name: Executive Dysfunction
nodes.description: Difficulty with planning, multitasking, and abstract thinking
nodes.role_in_PD: Tied to prefrontal cortex dopamine deficits and disrupted frontostriatal circuits

nodes.name: Dementia
nodes.description: Global cognitive impairment interfering with daily life
nodes.role_in_PD: Late-stage cognitive decline that may be associated with Lewy body pathology in cortical regions

nodes.name: Emotional Dysregulation
nodes.description: Difficulty in modulating emotional responses
nodes.role_in_PD: Linked to changes in amygdala function and altered monoamine (serotonin, dopamine) signaling

nodes.name: Anxiety
nodes.description: Persistent feelings of worry or apprehension
nodes.role_in_PD: Related to serotonergic and dopaminergic dysfunction, plus amygdala and hippocampal involvement

nodes.name: Depression
nodes.description: Persistent low mood and loss of interest
nodes.role_in_PD: One of the most common non-motor symptoms; linked to reduced monoamine transmission

nodes.name: Apathy
nodes.description: Loss of motivation and goal-directed behavior
nodes.role_in_PD: Associated with dysfunction in dopaminergic reward circuits (VTA-accumbens-prefrontal cortex)

nodes.name: Sleep Disturbances
nodes.description: Insomnia, restless sleep, or REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD)
nodes.role_in_PD: Related to degeneration in brainstem nuclei (e.g., raphe, PPN) and dysregulated neurotransmitter pathways

nodes.name: Autonomic Dysfunction
nodes.description: Issues with blood pressure regulation, digestion, sweating
nodes.role_in_PD: Due to degeneration of autonomic control centers and noradrenergic deficits (LC involvement)

nodes.name: Constipation
nodes.description: Reduced bowel movements
nodes.role_in_PD: Can precede motor symptoms; linked to enteric nervous system alpha-synuclein pathology

nodes.name: Orthostatic Hypotension
nodes.description: Drop in blood pressure upon standing
nodes.role_in_PD: Related to loss of autonomic control and noradrenergic neurons

nodes.name: Hyposmia (Reduced Sense of Smell)
nodes.description: Decreased ability to detect odors
nodes.role_in_PD: Early non-motor symptom, often correlated with alpha-synuclein pathology in the olfactory bulb

nodes.name: Fatigue
nodes.description: Excessive tiredness and lack of energy
nodes.role_in_PD: Multifactorial, related to motor effort, sleep problems, and neurochemical changes

nodes.name: Pain
nodes.description: Sensory discomfort varying in nature and severity
nodes.role_in_PD: Possibly linked to central sensitization, altered dopamine, and other neurotransmitter pathways

nodes.name: Hallucinations
nodes.description: Sensory perceptions (often visual) without external stimulus
nodes.role_in_PD: Linked to dopaminergic or cholinergic imbalances; often exacerbated by certain PD medications

nodes.name: Dopamine Dysregulation Syndrome (DDS)
nodes.description: Compulsive overuse of dopaminergic medications leading to behavioral changes
nodes.role_in_PD: Associated with reward circuitry dysregulation (e.g., VTA-striatal-prefrontal circuits)

nodes.name: Urinary Problems
nodes.description: Incontinence, urgency, or frequency issues
nodes.role_in_PD: Related to autonomic dysfunction in PD; measured by MDS-UPDRS Part I

nodes.name: Speech Difficulties
nodes.description: Soft speech (hypophonia), slurred articulation, or vocal tremor
nodes.role_in_PD: Results from bradykinesia/rigidity in orofacial muscles; measured by MDS-UPDRS Part II and III

nodes.name: Drooling (Sialorrhea)
nodes.description: Excess saliva due to reduced swallowing
nodes.role_in_PD: Caused by bradykinesia in oropharyngeal muscles; measured by MDS-UPDRS Part II

nodes.name: Chewing/Swallowing Difficulties
nodes.description: Impaired mastication or dysphagia
nodes.role_in_PD: Caused by rigidity/bradykinesia of the oromotor muscles; measured by MDS-UPDRS Part II

nodes.name: Walking Difficulty
nodes.description: Shuffling gait, difficulty initiating steps
nodes.role_in_PD: Related to bradykinesia and impaired postural reflexes; measured by MDS-UPDRS Part II and III

nodes.name: Pathological Gambling
nodes.description: Compulsive gambling behavior with negative personal/financial consequences
nodes.role_in_PD: Often associated with dopaminergic medication overuse and reward circuit dysregulation

nodes.name: Hypersexuality
nodes.description: Excessive or inappropriate sexual urges or behaviors
nodes.role_in_PD: Can arise due to dopaminergic therapy and changes in frontal-limbic pathways

nodes.name: Compulsive Shopping
nodes.description: Uncontrolled spending, over-acquisition of goods
nodes.role_in_PD: Linked to impulse control deficits, often exacerbated by dopamine agonists

nodes.name: Compulsive Eating
nodes.description: Excessive or binge eating behaviors without hunger
nodes.role_in_PD: Tied to dysregulated reward circuitry and sometimes dopaminergic medications

nodes.name: Punding
nodes.description: Repetitive, purposeless, often complex behaviors (e.g., sorting, disassembling objects)
nodes.role_in_PD: Associated with dopaminergic overstimulation, distinct from typical OCD rituals

nodes.name: Hobbyism
nodes.description: Excessive dedication to a hobby or activity beyond normal interest
nodes.role_in_PD: Falls under the ICD spectrum; can be driven by dopaminergic reward-seeking

nodes.name: Insomnia
nodes.description: Difficulty falling or staying asleep
nodes.role_in_PD: Common non-motor symptom in PD, often related to changes in sleep regulation

nodes.name: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder
nodes.description: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD) is a sleep disorder where individuals act out vivid dreams due to loss of normal muscle paralysis during REM sleep.
nodes.role_in_PD: Frequently precedes motor symptoms of PD and may be an early indicator of synucleinopathy

nodes.name: Excessive Daytime Sleepiness
nodes.description: Excessive Daytime Sleepiness is a condition characterized by persistent sleepiness and lack of energy during the day, even after adequate or prolonged nighttime sleep.
nodes.role_in_PD: Common non-motor symptom in PD, often related to dopaminergic dysfunction and reduced sleep drive

nodes.name: Hypersalivation
nodes.description: Hypersalivation is excessive saliva production, which can lead to drooling.
nodes.role_in_PD: Common non-motor symptom in PD, often related to bradykinesia and autonomic dysfunction

nodes.name: MDS-UPDRS
nodes.function: Movement Disorders Society-Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale
nodes.role_in_PD: Used to measure the severity of both motor and non-motor PD symptoms

nodes.name: MoCA
nodes.function: Montreal Cognitive Assessment
nodes.role_in_PD: Screens for mild cognitive impairment in PD, covering memory, attention, executive function, language, visuospatial abilities, and orientation

nodes.name: QUIP
nodes.function: Questionnaire for Impulsive-Compulsive Disorders in Parkinson's Disease
nodes.role_in_PD: Screens for impulse control disorders (ICDs) such as pathological gambling, hypersexuality, compulsive shopping/eating, and other behaviors

nodes.name: DaTscan
nodes.function: Dopamine transporter imaging technique used to differentiate Parkinsonian syndromes from essential tremor
nodes.role_in_PD: Assesses dopamine transporter availability in the striatum, aiding in the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease

nodes.name: SCOPA
nodes.function: Comprehensive assessment tool covering multiple domains of Parkinson's disease
nodes.role_in_PD: Scales for Outcomes in Parkinson's disease (SCOPA) is a comprehensive assessment tool covering multiple domains of Parkinson's disease, including motor function, cognition, sleep disturbances, psychosocial functioning, and autonomic dysfunction.

links.description: Alpha-synuclein is modified to Phosphorylated Alpha-synuclein
Parkin operates in same pathway as PINK1
DJ-1 opposes elevated release of Neurofilament Light Chain (NfL)
Tau Protein co aggregates with Phosphorylated Alpha-synuclein
Phosphorylated Tau (p-tau) co aggregates with Phosphorylated Alpha-synuclein
UCH-L1 cooperates in proteostasis with DJ-1
Dopamine regulates redox protection with DJ-1
Substantia Nigra pars compacta (SNc) produces Dopamine
Degeneration of Substantia Nigra pars compacta (SNc) leads to Bradykinesia
Nucleus Basalis of Meynert produces Acetylcholine
Degeneration of Nucleus Basalis of Meynert contributes to Cognitive Decline
Ventral Tegmental Area (VTA) projects dopamine to Prefrontal Cortex
Ventral Tegmental Area (VTA) projects dopamine to Hippocampus
Atrophy of Hippocampus contributes to Cognitive Decline
Amygdala dysfunction contributes to Emotional Dysregulation
Amygdala receives serotonergic input from Serotonin
Serotonin modulates emotional response in Amygdala
Reduced excitation in Motor Cortex contributes to Bradykinesia
Motor Cortex receives basal ganglia feedback from Striatum (Caudate/Putamen)
Hypoactivation of Prefrontal Cortex leads to Executive Dysfunction
Prefrontal Cortex depends on optimal levels of Dopamine
Subthalamic Nucleus (STN) influences Motor Cortex through basal ganglia circuit
Hyperactivity of Subthalamic Nucleus (STN) contributes to Bradykinesia
Dysfunction in Pedunculopontine Nucleus (PPN) contributes to Gait Disturbance
Pedunculopontine Nucleus (PPN) contains cholinergic neurons affecting Acetylcholine
Glutamate provides excitatory input to Pedunculopontine Nucleus (PPN)
Olfactory Bulb is an early accumulation site for Alpha-synuclein
Pathology in Olfactory Bulb causes Hyposmia (Reduced Sense of Smell)
Mutations in SNCA lead to Familial PD
LRRK2 (Gene) is the most common cause of autosomal-dominant Parkinson's Disease
Mutations in PRKN contribute to Mitochondrial Dysfunction
Mutations in PRKN lead to Early-Onset PD
Loss of function in PINK1 exacerbates Mitochondrial Dysfunction
Mutations in PINK1 (Gene) lead to Early-Onset PD
Mutations in PARK7 (DJ-1 Gene) increase Oxidative Stress
Mutations in GBA promote aggregation of Alpha-synuclein
GBA increases risk of Parkinson's Disease
VPS35 is essential for Protein Sorting
Mutations in VPS35 lead to a late onset form of Parkinson's Disease
Mutations in ATP13A2 cause Kufor-Rakeb Syndrome
PLA2G6 is involved in Phospholipid Metabolism
Mutations in PLA2G6 contribute to Neurodegeneration
Mutations in FBXO7 lead to Early-Onset PD
Bradykinesia arises from reduced input to Striatum (Caudate/Putamen)
Rigidity is linked to altered signal from Motor Cortex
Postural Instability is exacerbated by dysfunction in Pedunculopontine Nucleus (PPN)
Freezing of Gait is associated with overactivity in Subthalamic Nucleus (STN)
Cognitive Decline is affected by alpha-synuclein pathology in Hippocampus
Cognitive Decline is worsened by cholinergic deficits in Nucleus Basalis of Meynert
Executive Dysfunction is tied to dopamine loss in Prefrontal Cortex
Dementia correlates with accumulation of Phosphorylated Tau (p-tau)
Emotional Dysregulation is contributed by dysfunction in Amygdala
Depression is linked to low levels of Dopamine
Depression is partly due to deficit in Serotonin
Apathy is associated with reduced activity in Ventral Tegmental Area (VTA)
Sleep Disturbances are impacted by serotonergic changes in Raphe Nuclei
Autonomic Dysfunction is exacerbated by loss of noradrenergic tone in Locus Coeruleus
Constipation is linked to enteric accumulation of Alpha-synuclein
Orthostatic Hypotension reflects a deficit in Norepinephrine
Hyposmia (Reduced Sense of Smell) is caused by pathology in the Olfactory Bulb
Pain is modulated by levels of Dopamine
Hallucinations are exacerbated by excess Dopamine
Cognitive Impairment is linked to dopamine deficit in Prefrontal Cortex
Dopamine Dysregulation Syndrome (DDS) involves overstimulation of Ventral Tegmental Area (VTA)
Speech Difficulties are related to impaired signal to orofacial muscles in Motor Cortex
Walking Difficulty underlies basal ganglia miscommunication with Striatum (Caudate/Putamen)
Memory Impairment is exacerbated by pathology in Hippocampus
Attention Impairment is linked to dopamine deficit in Prefrontal Cortex
Visuospatial Deficits involve dysfunction in Parietal Cortex
Language Difficulties contribute to word finding problems in Prefrontal Cortex
Orientation Problems worsen with Cognitive Decline
Pathological Gambling is driven by excess activity of Dopamine
Hypersexuality is exacerbated by medication induced changes in Dopamine
Compulsive Shopping is associated with overactivity within Nucleus Accumbens (NAc)
Compulsive Eating is influenced by reward pathway dysfunction in Nucleus Accumbens (NAc)
Hobbyism is associated with excess dopaminergic drive from Ventral Tegmental Area (VTA)
Punding is linked to chronic overstimulation of Dopamine
DaTscan assesses transporter availability of Dopamine
DaTscan measures dopaminergic deficit in Striatum (Caudate/Putamen)
DaTscan reflects dopaminergic neuron loss in Substantia Nigra pars compacta (SNc)
DaTscan can indicate risk of Executive Dysfunction
DaTscan can indicate risk of Cognitive Decline
SCOPA-Motor subscale assesses Freezing of Gait
SCOPA-Sleep subscale assesses REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD)
SCOPA-Sleep subscale assesses Excessive Daytime Sleepiness
SCOPA-AUT subscale assesses overall Autonomic Dysfunction
